I'm an indoor chick anyway, because I hate the hot sticky weather we get in the valley, but I'm feeling very self-conscious every time I go out now. Time for a fudgsicle, I think.

Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2010 07:45AM algreach wrote: Welcome to the new folks! Jezzeetoms, we're happy to have you on the thread, and I wish your mom all the best as she goes through treatment. Day 3 Tx 1 was pretty uneventful except I suffered a brief bout of constipation, then the exact opposite, accompanied by a nasty burning sensation. I'm grateful for the chemo purchase list thread that suggested getting baby wipes. That's all I'm going to say about that. No nausea yesterday, thank goodness. I did my two daily walks with the dog, and ate fairly well. I had a slight sour taste in my mouth for most of the day, so some foods did not appeal. Fruit was fine, saltines were heavenly, and country chicken & brown rice soup really hit the spot. I'm being very diligent but gentle with my mouth care, and so far, no sores. Hope everyone else is doing well.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 08:43AM algreach wrote: Danielas--I'm sure you can bring your laptop; don't know what the internet connection will be like, tho. I'll be thinking about you. I had originally planned to go to my first treatment alone, and then my brother got the day off work. I'm very independent and I often prefer being alone, but I've started to realize that this disease is affecting the people around me, too. My brother wants to help and doesn't know how. Coming with me to treatments makes him feel like he's doing something constructive. So, I let him. :-) My onc said I would most likely be able to drive home afterwards--and after my tx, I certainly felt alert and capable. I plan to drive myself whenever my brother isn't available.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2010 06:08AM algreach wrote: Add me to the June group. I start Jun 2nd with FECx3, Tx3. I had my PICC put in yesterday and I'm as ready as I'll ever be, I guess. Jun 2nd is my daughter's 16th birthday. :-( I asked her if I should change the appointment, but she said she wanted me on the road to recovery sooner rather than later. She's such a great kid. I don't want it to be a downer event, though, so I'm hosting the party this weekend instead of next--while I still have energy. Daniela--Thanks for starting this thread. It looks like you and I are on the same regimen. It does seem so much more real now that chemo is right around the corner. Sherry--Good luck with the onc appointment. I think the waiting is the hardest part. I'm 2 weeks out from my AND, too, and I'm sorry to hear your healing isn't going as speedily as you'd like. Is there a particular problem? I got cording just after my second op, which is no fun at all. MelMel--I have up and down days with the emotions. Most of the time, I'm just fine. Then out of the blue, I'll burst into tears. Doesn't last long, because I feel good knowing that I'm taking action against this miserable beast. I hope you have a terrific weekend before your Monday start. SKD--Good luck with your first treatment today!! Wishing you the very best experience and minimal SEs.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 02:54PM algreach wrote: Hmmm. I have gallstones, too. I didn't know I had them until I did all the staging tests--I've never had a gallstone attack. Beanius--Sorry to hear about the delay. Waiting is sooo hard. Suebean123--Taking charge is less stressful than waiting, but you ARE doing everything you need to do. The day of your first tx will be here before you know it. Angelwoman1--Yes, my 1st treatment went well, thanks! The anticipation is more frightening than the event.  tbyrd--You perfectly described how I feel: nothing tastes good but my tummy is bloated. :-( tammyg--Hope you're feeling a bit better. You certainly managed to keep your sense of humor.  twinmomjackie--Sorry to hear that you didn't end up with the plan you wanted. I seem to recall the plan you're on has excellent results, though. Good luck on Wednesday.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 04:24PM algreach wrote: Good luck to those of you starting treatment tomorrow--wishing you a swift and uneventful experience with mininmal SEs! Day 6 Tx 1 has been much the same as the last few days. But I'm starting to feel sore spots in my mouth that I pray do not become full blown mouth sores. I'm brushing, flossing (gently), and gargling Biotene, so hopefully everything will work out. Holli--You have such vibrant energy and a terrific attitude. I aspire to be you. :-) Danielas--Glad to hear everything went well!
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: May 29, 2010 03:34PM algreach wrote: Twinmomjackie--I'm not in a clinical trial for different drugs, but I participated in one for minimizing pain and maximizing ROM after surgery. RS711--I have a strong family history of BC--both my mom and my sister had it. My mom's family in Denmark also had a lot of BC in it. I'm going to have the genetic testing done, because in my case it makes a lot of sense, and I have a daughter who will probably want to know some day. Designer mom--The research I've done has all been focused on how well the treatment my onc proposed works, not whether there was something with fewer SEs, so I haven't got anything to add to your query. Fewer SEs sounds good, though! Good luck with whatever option you choose.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2010 05:31PM algreach wrote: Jenweg--congrats on the uneventful first treatment! I, too, survived my first treatment with no reactions. It'll be interesting to see how things progress, but so far so good. My hospital staff was great--they even provided a freezie pop while they injected one drug that was more likely to cause mouth sores. I've got my meds from the pharmacy and I'm determined to stay ahead of the nausea.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 06:20AM algreach wrote: Janny99--It can make a huge difference when the people helping us beat this beast into submission are kind, considerate and genuinely concerned for our wellfare. I'm glad your team was so responsive and reassuring. I would have been frightened in your shoes, but you sound wonderfully calm and composed! Here's hoping everything goes forward on schedule. So many brave ladies on this loop. You are all inspiring. Thanks for being here. Day 2 Tx 1: Still feeling okay, but a little 'off'. I've experienced a bit of nausea despite my Zofran, but I was given Stemetil/Compazine to take if the nausea rises, and I've been very quick to pop one if there's even a hint of stomach upset. So far, all I've had is some queasiness. Enough to wake me up in the middle of the night last night--but that could also be the steroids. I'm drinking like crazy trying to wash everything out. I swear, I've never swallowed this much water, juice and Gatorade in my life. My coffee doesn't taste as good as usual this morning, but I don't know if that's the drugs or my imagination.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 07:23AM algreach wrote: I have some minced ginger sweets I got a local store--I tried eating one yesterday but it was pretty spicy. My stomach didn't seem to mind it, tho. I'm trying to drink a lot of fluids, but with my coffee now tasting distinctly off and water boring me to tears, I'm switching around to almost every liquid i can think of--milk, water, gingerale, fruit juice, and even freezie pops.I'll have to try the ginger root tea. Still a vague sense of queasiness, but that's it so far. I haven't had to take anything extra for nausea (other than the Zofran) for the last 24 hours. I get home care, so a nurse came by yesterday to change my PICC dressing and check on me. My family all called in, and my brother-in-law made us dinner. I'm feeling very loved. :-) Hope all of you starting treatment next week have an awesome pre-TX weekend. Wishing minimal SE's to all of us who've got that first treatment out of the way.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 07:52AM algreach wrote: I'm on day 11 post Tx 1 and still feeling fine. I'm walking everyday and still consuming a lot of high fiber foods & water. No sign of hair loss or tingling scalp yet, though my hair is starting to feel like straw. My sister's going to cut my hair once it starts falling--I'm not sure I can trust myself not to cry at the salon. Glad to hear most of the latest post-treatment ladies are experiencing few SEs. Hugs to all of you who aren't feeling well.We will get through this. One treatment at a time. Best wishes for Roosje and TMarina as you have your first Tx tomorrow. We'll be thinking of you. Akitalover--I'm a single mom, so I understand how you feel about your husband being away and being on your own. I kept the phone nearby, just in case, but didn't need to use it. The anticipation was more scary than the days after my treatment. How terrific that your son might be able to help with the hair situation. :-)
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 08:04AM algreach wrote: Wow--we have quite the group now. Welcome to all the newcomers, and hugs to you all for what you're going through. Sorry I've missed greeting you as you've joined--the last few days of school for my teen daughter have been hectic. I bit the bullet and had my head shaved yesterday, too. I couldn't stand the hairs falling all over the place--some of them landing in my food. Eew. My sister, who is a 3 yr BC survivor, did it for me. I didn't cry. My daughter, sweet thing that she is, said she thought the new do made me look younger. LOL! I'm not thrilled to wear my wig, though. It looks good--almost like my real hair--but it feels strange and HOT. I  wonder if I can get away with just wearing a hat when I go out? Will the absence of hair be too obvious?

After that, I'll need testing before each session. To MelMel10 and HolliColorado: Good luck with your first treatments today! We'll be thinking of you!

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 02:36PM algreach wrote: Day 4, Tx 1 and I'm doing pretty good today. Coffee tastes good for the first time in several days. Yay! I'm still tired and most foods still don't appeal to me, but I'm eating anyway. Other than that, the SEs are minimal. Holli--Chemo cocktail party. :-) Love that! So sorry you're having such a rough time of it.Hopefully the change in your anti-nausea meds will improve the next round for you. Did the hike with your dog help you feel any better? chob--Glad you're off to the ER. Fingers crossed that the FEC will go as smoothly for you as it did for me. Is someone going with you? Or are you just bringing a book/music? Mari-12 and Janny66--Wishing you the best for your first treatments tomorrow, too. Mimi9186--Good luck with the port placement tomorrow. Best wishes for all you brave ladies this week.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2010 08:36AM algreach wrote: SDK--Hope all is well after you're 1st treatment last week. MelMel and Holli--Hope you're doing well today. Did everything go smoothly? Jenweg and mtf2518--I'll be thinking of you as I sit in the chemo chair today. Best wishes. mtf & janny99--This trip is an emotional rollercoaster. But you're amongst friends here and hopefully we'll all be stronger for the sharing of our experience.  Hugs to you both. I'm trying not be nervous, but it's hard.  :-)  I'm just filling up the hours between now and 2:30 so I don't dwell on what's to come. Drinking lots of water, going for a nice long walk with the dog, and doing chores I may not feel like doing later.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 02:45PM algreach wrote: Hi all! I'm pleased to report that a week after my first treatment, I seem to be back to normal. Or close. My mouth remains a bit sore, but most foods are tasting okay. I'm still a bit fatigued as well, but not enough to interrupt my day. Kittycat--How frustrated you must be with the delay. I hope they get this sorted out quickly. Janny99--I've had problems with my teenage daughter the past few days, and I know it's the stress getting to both of us. It doesn't help that exams are just around the corner. Sherry9316--My nurses said ALL fluids count. Soup, ice cream, and fruit included. Anything that gets liquid into your body is good. Caffienated drinks pull the liquid from your body, but they will still help flush the drugs out. Just make sure, as others have said, that you add in all sorts of otherfluids. I drank water and Gatorade, and as one of the other ladies mentioned, strawberry-banana juice. But I also consumed low-sodium soups--they went down really nice. MelMel10--Glad your thrush got treated. Thanks for the warning. Angelwoman1 & Isla--Thinking about you. Hope all is well. brat352--Must be nice to have that 1st tx out of the way. :-) Julia--My recommendation would be: liquids of all sorts, baby wipes, antacid, a fresh toothbrush, a tube of lip balm, Saltines, and daily Activia yogurt. Anyone else got suggestions? SKD--Are you 12 days out from your 1st tx? I was warned that anywhere between 12-14 days the hair would start to fall out. How long it takes is individual and dependent on your cocktail, but I was told that by three weeks most of my hair would be gone. My sister (who has been through this already) told me to wait until the hair starts to fall, then cut it very, very short. I have my wig already, and I'm anticipating the hairs to start falling. I've thought about going commando, but my head is both bumpy and small for my body. I think if I don't wear something, I'll scare myself, LOL. Good luck to Mimi and Designermom who are starting treatment tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 11:31AM algreach wrote: Add me to the hair-falling-out crew. It's coming out slowly, just today (Day 13). My head is sore in spots, too, SKD. Don't know why. I've read on other threads that some people get sore heads, but haven't found any info on when it stops. Thanks for the advice on cutting the hair short sooner rather than later. Mimi--Sorry to hear that you're not feeling well. I had nausea (mild) for about a week after my treatment, and a sore mouth and tongue for about as long). After that things started to feel better. Hopefully you'll start to feel better soon, too. Lots of love for you all, especially those having their fisrt treatment today.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2010 04:36AM algreach wrote: Hi all, I was diagnosed Mar 9th and I'm scheduled for a right breast MX on Apr 16. Up until now I haven't really thought about my surgery, because I was busy with a big work project. Now the project is done, and it's suddenly feeling very real. I'm just hoping everything goes well!  I'm a single mom and worry about how all of this is going to impact my daughter.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2010 06:16AM algreach wrote: Brigidko and lsf -- hope your surgeries went well; I'm thinking about you. CandyB - my daughter is 15 and is in total silent mode. I try to keep her informed on basics, but I don't share lots of details, because I know she's not in the right mental space to deal with them. She's a good kid and I know she'll help out a lot. But she worries, and she hasn't shared any of this with her friends. I fear she's internalizing a bit too much. What can I do but keep the door open for dialog, right? I had my pre-op appointment on Thursday: blood tests, EKG, etc. In  my neck of the woods, a simple MX + SNB w/no recon is a day surgery. They send you home the same day, with a nurse to check up on you day 2 and day 5. My sister, who had the same surgery three years ago said she did just fine. I'm hoping the same is true for me.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 08:34AM algreach wrote: Dustymom--Sorry to hear you're not feeling all that well. Good luck with your appointments on Monday. Hopefully the Drs will be able to get you more comfortable. Hantayo--Yay on the negative nodes! Glad to hear you came through surgery so well. Thanks to everyone for the extra exercises! I got a few in a booklet from my breast center (the standard walk finger up wall, lift arm over head until I feel a stretch, lift arm out to side until I feel a stretch, etc) but I never got any that suggested a circular motion and I find that one reaches some muscles the other don't. I'm a little bummed that I'll probably have to start the exercises from scratch after my AND, but at least I'm ready for it!

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 07:20AM algreach wrote: Jenweg - I feel the same way. I've been very calm until now, but the past two nights I've had trouble getting to sleep. I just lie there and worry--about everything. Crazy. I can't wait for Friday to have come and gone. Tamgam - I love that saying. I'm going to repeat it to myself daily. :-) Sending positive healing vibes to all those having surgery this week...
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 05:21AM algreach wrote: Sorry to hear that a few of you have have drain problems. Strangely, I didn't have any drains after my mx with SNB. My surgeon doesn't believe in them--which scared me silly because every where I looked on the 'net drains seemed to be the norm. I got a little bit of edema for a few days (worst on day 3), then everything settled down and my incision was in good shape before I headed into my axillary node dissection yesterday. Hugs to ssashland on the news and on the waiting. Waiting IS unbearable. Hugs to ordinary mammal on the infection, too. Your sense of humor rocks, though. :-) I, too, have had a few bouts of sudden weeping--they seem to hit me at the oddest times--but given what we're going through, probably not unexpected.I met my rad onc this week (meet the med onc on the 13th) and when he mentioned that I'd see him again after five months of chemo, it struck me hard how long my treatment plan is. I know I'll make it through, but wow. I won't be done everything until close to Christmas. I'm happy to report that my ALND went well. I was soooo not looking forward to another surgery, but my BS was so supportive and easy-going it made things a lot easier. In fact, everyone at the hospital was cheery and friendly. Gotta say, being surrrounded by smiling faces does soothe the soul. Thanks for being here, ladies! I know I don't comment much, but I DO lurk and read every post.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 07:25AM algreach wrote: Back at home after my surgery yesterday. Simple right side MX & SNB with no recon, so I'm feeling pretty good. I've got a tensor bandage on, which helped with the sleeping, I think. I haven't had to take anything stronger than Tylenol. I won't get the results of my nodes for 2 weeks, although the surgeon said they looked clean--which means no obvious cancer, no swollen nodes. I'm not a very patient person, and I hate all the waiting. But I'm rolling with the punches. To those of you anticipating surgeries next week, my thoughts are with you. May your surgeries be straightforward and your healing quick.  ((Hugs to all))
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 06:47AM algreach wrote: I got the news yesterday that 3 of 5 nodes removed during SNB are involved. I was expecting that news, because I have multi-centric, multi-focal disease and LVI, but it still knocked me for a loop.I was depressed all day yesterday. I don't want to go back into surgery--I'm just starting to feel more normal after my surgery on the 16th. I had significant swelling, and I have a couple of hematomas. :-(  But removing the rest of my nodes is the smart thing to do. I'll book the appointment for after my oncologist meeting. Sigh. Anyone here have an AND after their mastectomy?  Big deal, or not? Hope everyone who had surgery this week is doing well.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 02:25PM algreach wrote: Welcome to jdoubow and hope! hope--The lingo will second nature to you in no time. I'm just amazed at how much information exists on these loops. jdoubow--My mom had breast cancer twice and died in 2006. My sister was diagnosed with BC just few months later. Oddly, I never really thought I'd get BC, either. Don't know why. I've requested the genetic testing for the benefit of my third sister and my daughter. Everyone--I hope you're healing well!   As for me, this week did not go as well as last week. I got a whopping hematoma after my axillary clearance, and now I've developed cording. OUCH. I made an appointment to see a physiotherapist to see if I can conquer the cording sooner rather than later. I got my final path report this week and met with my med onc. I'll be starting chemo (FECx3/Tx3) in early June, as soon as my surgery is healed up.  Don't have an exact date yet. I've been reading the April and May chemo topics to get up to speed with this next stage. Have a great weekend, all!
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 04:45AM algreach wrote: I have yet to go for a mast bra and form fitting. I should do that. I  think the tissue is as flat as it's going to get. I'm six weeks out and the nerve 'chafing' feeling is finally starting to subside. The lump in my armpit from my ALND on May 7th has also decreased significantly. My cording is painful, but I just keep stretching--my PT appointment isn't until Jun 7th. My scar is the part that bothers me the most right now. Not the look, but the tightness and the lack of mobility in the skin. If it weren't for that and the cording, I'd have my full range of motion back. I massage the scar daily with cream and do all my stretches, but it still doesn't move much. Is that normal? jenweg, I start chemo on Wednesday, too. Trying not to think about it. :-)
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 31, 2010 04:58AM algreach wrote: Thanks, AnacortesGirl! I'll modify my scar massage and tone down my stretches. I probably overdid it. Am I the only one who gets frustrated and teary-eyed over how much all of this impacts day-to-day life? I used to be so independent, and now I have to ask for help with simple things. HantaYo--I use an oatmeal-based cream from Aveeno, fragrance free. Don't know if it's the best, but it stays on the surface long enough to make the massages easier, then soaks right in. I waited until all my scabs were gone before using the cream and doing massages.
